Title: Accessibility testing basics
Description:
Working | Components and Patterns

What is this skill?:

Accessibility testing basics involves using built-in browser tools and simple checks to ensure your prototype can be used by people with disabilities. This includes checking keyboard navigation, colour contrast, and screen reader compatibility.

Why is it important?:

â€¢ Legal requirement â€“ Public sector services must meet WCAG 2.1 AA standards

â€¢ Inclusive design â€“ Prototypes should represent accessible final products

â€¢ Early problem detection â€“ Catch accessibility issues before development

â€¢ User research validity â€“ Ensure all participants can use your prototype

Where to learn more:

â€¢ GOV.UK Service Manual: Testing for accessibility

â€¢ WebAIM: Quick reference guide

â€¢ WAVE accessibility checker

â€¢ axe DevTools browser extension

Title: Views and page templates
Description:
Working | Pages and Layouts

What is this skill?:

A view is the visual template that renders what users see in the browser. In the prototype kit, views are Nunjucks files in the app/views folder that combine HTML, design system components, and dynamic data. Views use template inheritance ('extends') to share common layouts across pages.

Why is it important?:

â€¢ Page creation â€“ Views are where you build the actual screens users interact with

â€¢ Consistency â€“ All pages automatically share the same layout through inheritance

â€¢ Efficiency â€“ Don't repeat header and footer code on every page

â€¢ Separation of concerns â€“ Keeping views separate from routes makes code more organised

â€¢ Template reuse â€“ Views can extend layouts and include partials

â€¢ Maintainability â€“ Change the layout once to update all pages

â€¢ Data display â€“ Views receive data from routes and display it dynamically

Where to learn more:

â€¢ GOV.UK Prototype Kit: Create pages

Title: What is POST and GET?
Description:
Working | Pages and Layouts

What is this skill?:

POST and GET are HTTP methods that determine how data is sent between the browser and server. GET requests fetch pages, while POST requests submit form data. Understanding these is essential for building interactive prototypes.

Why is it important?:

â€¢ Form submissions â€“ POST is used when users submit forms with their answers

â€¢ Page navigation â€“ GET is used when users click links or type URLs

â€¢ Data handling â€“ Knowing which method to use affects how you access user input

â€¢ Correct behaviour â€“ Using the right method ensures your prototype works as expected

Where to learn more:

â€¢ GOV.UK Prototype Kit: Pass data from page to page

â€¢ MDN Web Docs: HTTP request methods

Title: What is Routing?
Description:
Working | Pages and Layouts

What is this skill?:

Routing is the mechanism that determines which page to show when a user visits a URL or submits a form. In the prototype kit, routes connect URLs to views and control how users navigate through your prototype.

Why is it important?:

â€¢ User journeys â€“ Routes define the paths users take through your service

â€¢ Form handling â€“ Routes process form submissions and determine what happens next

â€¢ Dynamic content â€“ Routes can pass data to pages, enabling personalised experiences

â€¢ Branching logic â€“ Routes enable different paths based on user input

Where to learn more:

â€¢ GOV.UK Prototype Kit: Create routes

â€¢ Express.js routing basics
